10228383.review:
Disclaimer: This was one of my childhood favorites, and although I've replayed it a couple of times in recent years the nostalgia goggles are so tight they've become a part of my skull and cannot be removed. Tablespoons of salt required as condiment to this review.

TLJ is a slow-paced point-and-click RPG with a unique world concept and layered, realistic characters. The story is the primary draw, as it is both well written and executed with complimenting dialogue. You're put in the shoes of an accidental heroine with a personality to match her background as a struggling artist in a cyberpunk-age Venice. She, and many other characters in this game may not be immediately likeable, but are given genuine character devlopment throughout. Well-written characters, the lore and depth of the world are the crowning jewels of this game. It is rare to find such a profound world concept outside a game based on a traditional tabletop RPG system. While the physical exploration of the world is limited to relatively small, contained maps at a time, exploration is achieved hand-in-hand with the storytelling and puzzle-solving and not as an elaborate sidequest. Many secrets and hidden and revealed in dialogue and visuals, and there is more to the world than what April herself sees. You may want to take notes. 

In terms of Roleplaying, you cannot change April's character. You're not entirely playing the game as her, either. The player is like a ghost looking over her shoulder, she will talk to herself more like she's talking to you, but never remark upon your presence.

To address the gameplay, this is stricthly a point-and-click adventure. You will not be engaged in active combat, you will need to find ways to circumvent conflict and bridge gaps in the road. The puzzles can at times be archaic and occasionally absurd, but if you're patient and put occam's razor to good use you will find your way. If you fail to do this, or simply cannot handle puzzle-solving games, following a guide and playing this game just for the story is still worth it. 

The game's length is about 25-30 hours if you don't spend a lot of time solving the puzzles. This is enough time to unfold an epic cyberpunk/fantasy-hybrid tale in the pace that it deserves. This is a game where you do not start in medias res, and the ending is not rushed; everything happens in due time. 

I would recommend this game to lovers of good stories. I do not have enough experience with puzzle-games to remark upon the quality of TLJ as such, but I can say as a well-versed RPG player and bookworm that this is story worth experiencing. TLJ sets its' own expectations and fulfills them. [10/10]

10011375.review:
Escrito e produzido por Ragnar Tørnquist, The Longest Journey é o início de uma maravilhosa saga lançada pela norueguesa Funcom, hoje um estúdio voltado para MMORPGs como The Secret World e Age of Conan. Trata-se de um adventure bem tradicional, com direito a puzzles muito sem noção, como o relativamente famoso Rubber Duck; eventual combinação de itens e inúmeras linhas de diálogo. Mas ele brilha na história e, principalmente, em seus personagens. O segundo título da sequência chama-se Dreamfall (2006) o terceiro, Dreamfall Chapters (2014), atualmente lançado no mesmo formato episódico que a da Telltale.

Comecemos pela April Ryan, uma garota do interior que vive numa pousada localizada dentro de uma metrópole do século 23 e é estudante de Artes Visuais (rolou até uma identificaçãozinha aqui, hahaha). Para mim, ela é uma das, senão a melhor e mais bem-escrita protagonista feminina já concebida para videogames. Sério. Embora cada vez mais estejamos presenciando protagonistas incríveis nos últimos anos, como as boas surpresas da E3 deste ano, poucas chegam a receber uma profundidade tão significativa de psiquê e personalidade exploradas.

Em menos de meia hora de gameplay, April faz a ponte necessária para o jogo tornar-se engajante, exprimindo muito de seu carisma e personalidade o qual se sustentará até o fim. Há momentos divertidíssimos em que ela faz algum comentário cheio de ironia ou espirituoso, mesmo em situações um tanto sérias. Ela é, sem dúvidas, uma jovem de 18 anos muito crível, do tipo que você gostaria de ter como amiga. E a qualidade da escrita fica mais foda ainda com a dublagem excepcional de Sarah Hamilton e a qual está participando na continuação, felizmente.

Quase todo mundo com quem você interage, por mais secundário que seja, é surpreendentemente carismático. Dentre eles, há dois dos melhores amigos de April, que frequentam a mesma faculdade: Charlie e Emma. Charlie é um cara adorável e gentil que trabalha no The Fringe Café como atendente e é estudante de dança. Já Emma é especializada em “holoescultura” e fica de altas fofocas com a April, além de flertar com frequência. Os três vivem juntos na mesma pousada, The Border House.

A história por trás desse título é tão bacana que merece um parágrafo à parte. Fiona, dona do local e campeã dos diálogos espirituosos, conta que ela e sua tímida namorada, Mickey, se inspiraram nas pousadas inglesas clássicas do interior e decidiram adotar o formato. A ideia é que ele serviria como refúgio pra jovens estudantes e artistas pobres, e o “borda” no nome se dá tanto pela dicotomia espírito/tecnologia quanto pela pousada estar entre Venice e Newport.

Contada como um enorme flashback, a história começa quando o chamado “guardião do Equilíbrio” some repentinamente do seu local. Em seguida, logo depois que April nos é apresentada, ficamos sabendo que existem dois mundos interconectados e os quais começam a passar por problemas justamente pela falta do receptáculo necessário pra manter o Equilíbrio nos eixos. April, por sua vez, se envolve no problema a partir do momento que viaja involuntariamente para o mundo mágico de Arcadia durante um sonho. Isso vai se intensificando com o tempo e mais informações são reveladas através de um homem excêntrico de sotaque carregado chamado Cortez. Sua postura com a garota nas primeiras horas do jogo é bem sintetizada quando diz: “You see, señorita, mystery is important”.

A partir daí, acompanhamos a protagonista com seu grande dilema de carregar uma responsabilidade absurda nas costas (de salvar dois mundos), arriscar a pele várias vezes em prol das outras pessoas/criaturas, lidar com seus demônios internos – especialmente envolvendo o pai, outrora violento – e com um poder de viajar entre as duas realidades que sequer tem domínio. Além de, é claro, ser vista por muitos como a provável nova guardiã do Equilíbrio, substituído a cada mil anos. A pressão vem praticamente de todos os lados.

Essa descrença diante de um mundo mágico, o atrito entre “ciência” (no sentido do senso comum) e magia, somado ao destino de mundos nas mãos de uma única pessoa pode soar bastante clichê (e soa mesmo). Mas confie em mim quando digo que o desenvolvimento da história vai muito além dessa humilde resenha, mostrando um lore riquíssimo para esse universo fantástico.

Nessa (realmente) longa jornada, durando pelo menos umas 20 horas e dividido em 13 capítulos, um monte de acontecimentos se desenrola no que equivale a cerca de uma semana no mundo de April. Mas é tanta coisa uma atrás da outra que eu, pelo menos, tive uma enorme dificuldade de acompanhar tudo =P o que eu escrevi aqui nada mais é do que uma mera fração do conteúdo do jogo.

Mesmo se a sua tolerância a adventures mecânica e graficamente datados não for das maiores, ou até mesmo se adventures não for sua praia, pegue um guia e dê uma chance ao jogo. De verdade. Ele é bom demais pra deixá-lo passar batido, e mais ainda se você também ama uma boa história salpicada de momentos engraçados.

9744459.review:
[i]The Longest Journey[/i] is a [i]phenomenal[/i] story in a decent game. The world building is amazing, the settings are gorgeous, the voice acting is Hollywood quality, and the story itself is one of the best I've ever seen. If you're like me, and drawn more towards the story in a game than the actual gameplay, buy this immediately. The game is visually stunning, even when you take into account the late-90's CGI characters. Their animations are a bit slow and clunky, but to me, the beautifully rendered 2-D backgrounds more than compensated. And the characters themselves were so well thought out and well-rounded, with stories and lives beyond the game, combined with top notch voice acting, that it makes me care a lot less about what they looked like.

That being said, I felt the gameplay was a little flat. Some of the puzzles were pretty obscure, and there was a lack of in-game hints (there were times I had absolutely no idea even what puzzle I was meant to solve; I think they really missed the opportunity to make April's diary more helpful in that respect). And, like most point-and-click games, there is no danger if you get things wrong-- the game just won't progress until you do them correctly-- and replay value is, unfortunately, nil. It dragged in a few places, either from the clunky character animations, or just too much dialogue, and I often felt more like a passive watcher of events than the main character out to save the world.

Storywise, there's not many games out there that can compare to [i]The Longest Journey[/i], and in the end, the story is one of the most important aspects of a game to me. As it is, I'd rate this an 8.5/10. I think if it had just been a [i]little[/i] more interactive, or maybe had some alternate endings, it would have been the perfect game for me, late-90's CGI and all.

9708842.review:
Best point and click adventure game I’ve ever played. Up there, if not more enjoyable than The Curse of Monkey Island, Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars and The Walking Dead - I can see now why it is scored so highly.

First of all The Longest Journey no doubt requires a lot of patience. The game shares more familiarities with a novel, having an extraordinary amount of dialogue to go through and numerous objects to click on and explore. Story felt refreshingly unique and flows well. It is split into thirteen Chapters of varying length and themes. The voice acting is brilliant – characters feel natural, not samey and often time’s humorous (mature content).  

Puzzles on reflection were mostly straight forward, logical and challenging – and only had to use a guide for small sections of the game that didn’t make sense or where I forgot one piece of dialogue (you need to complete certain things in order to continue with the plot). Graphics and cut scenes look dated at first impression but soon becomes part of the games charm. Musical soundtrack does a fantastic job at conveying the different moods throughout the journey.

Chapter Three is the funniest, and cements the fact that this is now one of my favourite point and click games. Definitely a masterpiece.

10/10

I have nothing against old point-and-click games; in fact, I've played a fair few recently and they're often still really good. This one came about during a love-in with pre-rendered 3D art, before nice art styles became common, so unfortunately it looks very ugly. It's got obtuse puzzles with obscure solutions. tediously slow dialogue, and I had to admit defeat when I came across a game-halting logic bug that stopped me from progressing any further without starting from the beginning again.
Some of the writing is good, perhaps progressive for its time, but I can't recommend anything else about it. Also please note, this game is not optimised for widescreen and I had to spend far too long getting it to display at the correct aspect ratio. No, it wasn't worth it.

9315875.review: The Longest Journey is Ragnar Tornquist and Funcom's first exploration into the epic world of point-and-click adventure gaming. This game's story and puzzles keep you moving, keep you guessing, and while sometimes a touch abstract, keep you interested. It weaves a startling and very interesting tale of crossing worlds, overcoming your own weaknesses, friendship, and good old-fashioned ingenuity.

9313080.review:
I'm fully aware that this game is incredibly dated by this point and stuff like graphics and animation I won't factor into this, not that I really tend to care about them anyways.

It's hard to really find how I feel about this though. On one hand, it's got pacing problems all over the place. The game's divided into 13 chapters, but not really, since some of the chapters are four times as long as others. And the game spends too much time worldbuilding; I can understand a certain extent of it but characters go too far in-depth about tiny things that won't ever be mentioned again. There's a lot of talking, also. A lot of talking. And plenty of instances where it will take you 15-20 seconds to run across a screen; and there's the option of walking it, too...
Plus, the game is admittedly kind of hard to take seriously due to its datedness. The CGI cutscenes where you get close-ups on the characters' faces... the stiff animations... I found myself laughing at some of the most tense scenes in the game because of that.
The story itself is also kind of cliched, but that's kind of the point. The main character, April, is in fact entirely aware of how cliche it gets, which kind of makes it permissable and enjoyable. The gameplay is standard point-and-click stuff. The puzzles aren't the most obscure but they can be tricky and the slooow pacing can make them more annoying than necessary.
Really though the major issue I do have with this game is its pacing, I still enjoyed it but if it had better pacing I'm sure I'd have enjoyed it even more.

9110181.review: I have somewhat mixed feelings about this game.  It was perhaps the most epic, involved, creative, and intelligent story I've come across in a game.  At the same time the writing and voice-acting are uneven across the entirety of the game.  Some clever humor is appreciated, but it too often strayed into just plain corny and bad.  The voice-acting was not very convincing on the whole, kept afloat only by the smart dialogue.  The puzzles were good overall, but at times quite inane and illogical.  Some of the solutions just weren't logical and I don't know how anybody would have figured them out on their own.  Also keep in mind that this game is nearly 15 years old.  The graphics may have been good when the game was originally released and some of the environments are nice, but by today's standards, the graphics are extremely poor.  The characters are at times gruesome looking regardless of how long ago they were produced.  Overall though, it's a classic point-and-click adventure that is worth your time if only for one of the most epic stories ever told in videogaming.

8935083.review:
The Longest Journey does its name justice. It is an epic adventure from beginning to end and it never gets tedious or boring like a lot of adventure games tend to do when they try to forcefully increase the playtime. The setting is unique, intriguing and creates a great atmosphere. The plot is original and inspiring and shows what adventure games can do when they're done right. The brightest aspect of the game, however are the characters. From the heroine to the minor characters, they are all wonderfully designed with a certain integrity that makes them incredibly powerful. They bring the story to life and make for a truly memorable game. This could not have been done without the excellent writing and voice acting. The only argument I have against the game's excellence is the pacing and execution of the lest stretch before the finale, which compared to the rest of the game seemed rushed. It seems as if the development team was not able to give this segment the attention and devotion that it deserved. It is a small issue barely worth mentioning however, since the rest of the game shines brightly.

If adventure games are your thing, this is a must-play.

8260542.review:
TLJ is an asthonishing blend of sci-fi and fantasy that flows on a linear progression, sans most point and click adventure games, but the pacing is smooth and you'll never be stuck in a single area for long periods of time. The story itself can be really intense at times and for the most part doesn't give in to jarring plot conveniences. The writing, brainchild of Ragnar Tornquist, is great as well. Usually protagonists, or characters in general, can be two extremes: really swell, or really annoying. If they fall inbetween they are bland. Tornquist's writing makes protagonist April Ryan annoyingly believable. Her mannerisms will constantly remind you that she's just a college student and not someone fit to save two worlds.
Spec-wise, the game came out in '99, and to my knowledge there are no HD mods or anything, and if this bothers you, start to notice the scenery more. The backgrounds in this game are gorgeous and they really amplify the atmosphere. 
The gameplay has some good puzzles. They aren't very hard, but they do the job. Also you can't die. To me this is a safer approach than other pointnclicks like Sierra games where you are punished for not knowing what was ahead of you ahead of time and it doesn't create anxiety for the sake of defibrilatting action into otherwise bland gameplay like The Walking Dead. If you like sci-fi or fantasy this is a game to check out, if you find it on sale that is. I really enjoyed it.

7950129.review:
An old classic, this game is one of the best experiences for quest-lovers.
the game is rather solid, length-wise, i clocked at 30 hours of gameplay, which is impressive, we are talking about "the longest" journey after all.
The dialogue in this game is really powerful and it helps you to connect with different characters, and some of them are really cool and interesting.
This game requires the player to think, like any good Click and Point Adventure should, but by no means is it a quick pased game, it's rather slow pased but really rewarding, like an interactive book of some sort.
The puzzles are challenging and quite cryptic, i was sitting on some of them for more than 25 minutes, and when i was able to solve such a puzzle i was extremely pleased.
the Graphics, however, did not age well. You are forced to play this game at 640x480 resolution, which really is an eyesore.
All in all, if you are looking for a game with great plot and dialogue and can overlook the distasteful graphics, this game is a must.

7934480.review:
This game really is among the very finest "point-and-click" adventure game that has ever been made.  The controls aren't particulary complex.  Left-click, right-click, Esc for the save menu, click to skip through dialogue.  Pretty standard.  The graphics looked dated when the game was new, and by today's standard they're antique.  Puzzles are pretty logical, and not very difficult.  Death is impossible.  But none of that is the reason you want to play this game.

TLJ has one of the most incredible stories ever told in interactive format.  It's like playing through an epic-length novel in 15 or 20 hours of gameplay.  The voice cast is outstanding from front to back.  The lead character, April Ryan, is likable and intelligent, and by the end of the game, you'll feel like you know her, and you'll be sorry to see her go at the end of the game.  Despite being dialogue-heavy, this game is never boring.  The plot advances with every puzzle solved, every character spoken to.  The cultures of two entire worlds are brought into conflict through April Ryan.

April is an art student in a slightly-dystopian, near future version of our world, a high-technology two-class society.  Magic doesn't exist there any more than it does in real life.  But April gets involved in a complicated plot that finds her being trapped in a parallel universe on a world called "Arcadia," where magic is real, and technology is sparse.  April occasionally goes back and forth between worlds, and even into space, in order to save Arcadia and her own world, and in the process learns a lot about herself.

Best $10 you could spend on Steam.

I can see that this game took an incredible amount of work and I'm sure many of the games themes will appeal to a certain audience but I just couldn't get into it.

Apparently this game is one of the longest point and click adventure games of all time. Trust me, I believe it.

I like to consider myself a patient person but this game has way too much dialogue for its own good. It's hard for me to stay engaged when conversations go on forever and most of the dialogue is fluff. I'm sure I'd give this game another shot if they just trimmed the fat and focused on more of the core themes of the story.

They tried far too hard to make April a normal everyday girl and maybe they have succeeded to an extent. But she doesn't come off as relatable, or heroic, or even interesting, she's just all around bland... and whinny. So, damn, whinny. This wouldn't be so bad if the side characters were interesting. There are a few here and there that are, but not enough to slog through the entire game.

I'm sure there are people who would enjoy this game for what it is but I expect my games to engage me on some level, whether conceptually, emotionally, or through raw stimulation. I was patient and kind to this game and was left feeling as if it wasn't worth my time.

Not recommended unless you are a die-hard adventure fan.

7755066.review:
Upon completing the Longest Journey, I wasn't surprised it constantly gets ranked in top PC game lists. 

Clocking in at a solid 25 hours, it will keep you entertained for quite a while. You do have to put yourself into the Click and Point Adventure mindset however, as it is by no means, a fast paced game. It's more like an interactive book.

The game for me shined the most in its dialogue. Nearly every character has an incredibly natural enunciation rarely found in games. It gives you a stronger connection with them, and helps you believe every word.

The next best parts of the Longest Journey was its story and variety of characters. It takes place in the 23rd century Venice, and gives a fascinating perspective of the past, present, and future. With a story as interesting as this, that's all I can really say without spoiling anything.
The characters feature a wide range of tallent and personallity, which makes them so interesting to talk to. By the first sentence someone utters, you already know what kind of person he/she is, and how he/she is going to treat you, it really is that detailed.

For a game stuck in 640x480 resolution, it is full of very detailed and beautiful scenery. 3D objects are pretty pixelated and jaggy, and are probably the thing that aged the worst. Some up-resing would benefit The Longest Journey pretty well, but I quickly became lost in everything else it had to offer, that the quality rarely bothered me.

The puzzles as well can be pretty cryptic. I had to look up a guild many times to figure out what to do next. That didn't bother me too much either, but it would have been nice if the main character gave hits on what to do.

I am currently working through the sequel, Dreamfall, which early on already has reoccuring characters and locations, and because it came out 6 years after the first, it's nice to see things in better detail.

If you want a less action oriented experience that feels like a mix of an interactive painting and a best selling novel, I highly recommend picking up the double pack. With a promising 3rd installment in the works, how can you go wrong?

7707233.review:
If you look for story in your games above all else, like me, then you may want to try The Longest Journey.

Pros:
 -The world presented in the longest journey is extremly detailed and interesting, tons of depth.  If you like to take your time an experience the world of your games, then this one won't let you down
 - The story is exciting and engrossing, lots of twists and turns.
 - The game has a great sense of humor, but it doesn't take away from the serious aspects of the game at all
 -A game that is actually well written, what a surprise.

I don't really want to spoil any plot elements, I sugest you just jump right in and don't look back.
But of course the game isn't perfect, it falls into some of the same problems a lot of older adventure games faced.

cons:
 -Solutions to some puzzles and just absurd or nonsense.
 -lots of running back and forth especially early in the game, especially if you happened to miss an item you were meant to pick up along the way (trust me you will)
 -Graphics, the game is old you can't fault it that much.
- Movement feels kind of clunky, it's not that big of a deal, but might as well mention it.

Overall I think the pros outweigh the cons greatly in this game, and it is worth looking into for anyone that appreciates good stories in games.

4435622.review: This is the Holy Grail of classic point and click adventure games! The story is masterfully written, it's witty, dark, and thoughtful and dare I say...this truly is an epic tale. April is a smartly written lead who is relatable and I found myself becoming attached to her as she treks through two parallel universes. 74213.review:
With more than 25+ hours of adventure, The Longest Journey certainly lives up to its title--man this game is long winded. Overall, this is a fantastic fantasy point-and-click adventure, although the beginning doesn't really do a good job at being captivating so I'm sure a lot of players quit prematurely never actually giving it a chance. I also got a little fatigued near the end as well, but by that time there was no way I was bailing out. Now I'm actually getting excited to play the sequel and also to learn about the upcoming 3rd episode due in 2014.

The one sad part is the game can only be played at 640x480 resolution and the graphics and animations did not age well making for some serious sore eyes. Thankfully, the story more than made up for it--absolutely classic.

3708713.review:
There are a lot of stale fantasy games out there. Games about men with swords and false British accents fighting monsters and animals alongside Dwarves and Elves. Few are the games which can truly create a unique world full of unique creatures and characters, and a unique story to go along with it. The Longest Journey is proof that, if nothing else, those sword & Elf games are just being lazy.

The Longest Journey is a good title, I feel. There's plenty lot of plot, and it's pretty important. Seeing the plot through to its conclusion is also important. But in this game, I wouldn't hesistate for a moment to say that the journey is far more important than the destination. For all the characters, I can't think of one that I didn't like - hero, villain, or neutral. From an egotistical wizard, to a short-tempered and superstitious captain, to the duly unloved police force, to your ladies' bird sidekick, to Burns Flipper, they're all memorable in their own way. And all of the races you'll meet along the way - the complexly-named ones who sing to the soil, the tense-confused ones who experience their entire lives simultaneously and the flying ones who hold storytelling in one's own words to be integral to their culture, to name only a few - are so fascinating that for all the time spent learning about each of them, I'm a little bummed out that I couldn't learn more.

The places you go are as wonderful as they are mysterious, and are only made moreso by the clash between the two worlds - the technological world of Stark, and the magical world of Arcadia. When I first visited the Haven Age of Myst IV: Revelation, I was greeted with stormy skies, a rough ocean, and an upturned shipwreck, all looming ahead. Once I climbed the nearby rock and peered over the other side, I saw bright skies, and a colorful, inviting jungle. The sheer wonder of this clash stopped me solid in my tracks, leaving me to admire the sharply contrasting views for some time before finally moving on.

This is what The Longest Journey is like *all the time*. Just on a much larger scale.

The journey is indeed long, for an adventure game. It's not always entirely forgiving; there are one or two infamous moon logic-y puzzles that are sure to frustrate, but please don't let them dissuade you. Barring those moments, The Longest Journey is such a lovingly crafted adventure, full of twists and turns, technology and magic, characters and exploration, and Burns Flipper, and it's all held together by April Ryan, our caring but sarcastic protagonist. April Ryan is, in my own opinion, the best-written female character of any video game I've ever played. And it's a good thing too, given the sheer amount of dialogue she has, all vocalized perfectly by Sarah Hamilton.

I play a lot of adventure games. The Longest Journey is without a doubt one of the best I have ever played, and I cannot recommend it enough. It's creative, it's well-written, it's mostly well-voiced, the majority of the puzzles make sense, and April only looks terrifying in the FMVs. Don't be on the fence about this one. Get it.

3715548.review:
Wow... What can be said about this game? It is perhaps not a masterpiece, but it is definitely something I cannot call a large majority of other games. It is simply a treat. Despite the lack of refined technology at the time it was released, never have I experienced a story so engaging or characters so vibrant, varied, and alive. If you are looking to be challenged, the puzzles you come across aren't terribly difficult or anything, but they are well-thought out and are very appropriate to the numerous settings you encounter them in. In addition to the amazing concept art and backgrounds, the voice acting is also surprisingly good.

This game really set the standard for click-and-point adventure games -- a genre that is often getting overshadowed by fast-paced shooters and high-action hack-and-slashers these days. There is indeed a reason its Metacritic score is so high. This is a beautiful game that was lovingly crafted. I would go so far as to say that it's nearly more than a game. It's an experience... and one that needs to be had. It does many things that present-day games too often lack, and it does them well.

If you haven't already, I beg you to play The Longest Journey. You will not regret it.

2973973.review: TLJ was and still is one of the finest stories in video games and one of my absolute favorite games. If you like adventure and/or story-driven games, buy this game its one of the very best.

940010.review:
I feel very cheated by this game. I was promised an experience, not any experience, but the ability to experience what is known as "The Longest Journey".

I go back to their proficiency (or lack thereof!) in the name, because it's key to what makes this so special-- if not successful. What is shown by the game is far less engrossing than how they amplify that, sometimes excruciatingly, until the pointing, clicking, and adventuring is raised to a gale force bellow. You're pulled so close to the guts of the mouse that by the end you'll think you could build one yourself.

The first half of "The Longest Journey" simulates how it must feel to be eaten alive-- at least until the second half, when player one attempts to eschew the paradigm, drowning in it. But in the back half of the game, the storm ends and it = switches to a hush. "The Longest Journey" is ambient and gentle, almost absent-mindedly turning upbeat at the end, and "The Longest Journey" grows so static that it's not even a dirge: It's lovely to play but bereft of tension.

Which is why I'm so curious about whether it's actually "good", if "good" even has a meaning at all (it doesn't).  Like early Pink Floyd, it, (both player and game as a one-self 'playergame'^[1]^[2]) engaged in an exploration that was unrehearsed and maybe even naïve. The game tried to become something other than the sum of its parts-- and by emerging from free and unrehearsed improvisation, the game resisted containers; the wails and ballads emerged organically, and their apparent goal-- of creating spontaneous, non-idiomatic, and exhilarating adventure-- was reached again and again, if only by proxy through existence.

It feels like the game wings itself in front of us-- thrilling us with new discoveries one minute, and the next, batting around ideas that go nowhere. Is the organ lineup here to stay? (Probably not) Is the pervasive melancholy a stylistic choice, a side effect of playing without truth, or an emotional reaction? Does "The Longest Journey" survive, evolve, or die?^[3] Whatever the future holds, this is some of the riskiest improv ever recorded: In every moment of the game, you just wish you actually went on the journey which was in fact, in the longest, but you just fucking don't.

Footnotes:
1: As put fourth by Charles Montagu Doughty in The Titans.

2. Also referenced by name in a song^[1] by the Beatles.

3. People die in real life as well. (It's true^[2])

Sub-Footnotes:
1. By another person's name: Charles Hawtrey

2. Truth is subjective^[1]

Sub-sub-footnotes:
1. Subjective is what someone calls music when they are told they have bad taste.

3915660.review:
Be Forewarned: This is a pretty old game and you may have trouble running it on modern machines. I personally encountered the "No FMV/Cutscenes playing" problem until i had to set my Power Options to "High Performance" which solved the issue. This solution may, or may not work for you.

This review may also contain minor puzzle spoilers.
==================================================

The Longest Journey is a graphic adventure game that was released back in 1999 by Funcom. During its time, it was hailed as one of the best graphic adventure games ever made (which i never played. I was more interested in Lucasarts and Sierra games in those days).

The most important element for any good adventure game is a good story, and this game most certainly delivers, although sometimes abit too much. It starts off simple enough, about an 18-year old art student April Ryan, her daily frustrations about school and boys until she starts having strange dreams and visions. What follows next is a mind bending over-the-top story plot spanning 12 chapters that will involve parallel universes and saving the very essence of reality. This is a very complex story indeed but can sometimes be too complex due to the many story jargons it throws at you and may be kindda hard to follow at times.

The art style have not aged very well. While the background art still does somewhat holds up well enough although barely, the 3D character art looks extremely dated. The look is reminiscent of early 90s 1st generation attempts at 3D characters in a video game. While this may be passable in 1999, it definitely looks ancient now in 2013, though I certainly cannot fault it for that. The game also runs at at maximum of 640 x 480 resolution, so it will look extremely pixellated running at full screen on modern widescreens. Sadly, there was never any "HD" patch ever made.

Gameplay wise, it adheres to the "Lucasarts" gaming philosophy where you will never ever come to a premature Game Over screen just because you forgot to pick up a tiny crucial object 30 screens before. Thankfully it also does not have any timed action sequence QTEs, although there is a very insignificant one at one of the later chapters, which can be easily done. The player need only focus on the story and puzzle solving.

As with any adventure games, puzzles are always the meat of the game, and unfortunately some of the puzzles in this game can have very obscure solutions. (I'm looking at you "Telephone Statue" puzzle). More then once, i had to consult a walkthrough because some of the solutions are too cryptic. Alot of times, i also had to resort to the "Use everything in my inventory until something works" tactic.

The puzzles are also definitely anything but subtle so to speak, and are put there for no apparent reason other then to present a challenge for the player to solve instead of it having a functional and logical use in the world. Alot of puzzles don't make alot of sense in their solutions. (Eg: Minor Spoilers: Who in their right mind would go touch a digusting green gloop on the ground that probably looks radioactive? Or dance around like a mad loon just because they see a shadow telling them to dance?" Basically don't use logic when you try to solve the puzzles, think "out of the box" instead.

Before wrapping up this review, theres something else that i'd like to add in that once you finished the game, you will unlock an extra option called "Book of Secrets" which is a collection of voice acting outtakes and unused/concept art that were used in the development of the game. This is considered to be quite a rare addition especially for a game released in 1999 where such bonus additions were rarely seen.

Overall Rating: 7.0 / 10
For old-school hardcore adventure gamers who appreciate a very complex story and don't mind tackling very obscure puzzles, this is definitely a game you should pick up. For younger gamers however, i'd recommend if you can watch a video preview before committing to it, as this game definitely shows its age now.

4385757.review:
The Longest Journey by Funcom takes us on April Ryan's adventure to save the world(s)! I didn't know what to expect from this game, especially since I'm not a huge fan of point-and-click adventure games, but The Longest Journey is easily the best p-a-c game I've ever played, and is a highly worthwhile title for its story alone. The backgrounds are beautifully done, but the character models are quite dated; that said, that doesn't really matter, because the writing, world-building, and characterization are incredibly manufactured and suck you so deeply into this adventure you soon don't care about looking at a blocky April texture. Seriously, there are more memorable characters in this game than the last several games I've played *combined*. Crow, The Wheel Man, The Flipster, and especially April - she's an incredibly *real* character. I'm just flabbergasted how well Funcom has pulled her off. She seems just like an 18 year old girl would, and the rest (or most important) of the characters are equally deep and interesting. To add to this characterization, the voice acting is also outstanding (mostly, there were a few poor ones) and...I just really can't get over how real April was, I honestly feel like I know her, and the rest of the characters too - they're very dynamic and just so well done. There are also lots of dialogue choices to pick through that don't pertain to *immediate* story progression used to flesh out the worlds and the characters - this was much appreciated, and made the created universe feel large and dynamic. There were other nice features as well: the setting was very unique, there was a video replay option to view the FMVs, nicely done music...However, the downfall of any point and click adventure game are the puzzles. Some are very convoluted. I remember one where you had to make a fishing pole out of some kind of string, an inflateable duck, and a bandaide. It was just too much for me, I admit, I used a walkthrough. That said, I would recommend using a walkthrough if you get stuck in this game - it's definitely worth playing, even for a p-a-c adventure game. 

Pros:

Excellent (like really) characterization and world building
Music
Backgrounds
Storyline

Cons:

Convoluted puzzles
A little too much backtracking at times

This was a great adventure, after playing it I'm really excited to move on to Dreamfall and I've also kept my eye on the kickstarter for the new Chapters that's coming out. I'm now a bonafide TLJ fan. Even if point and click adventure games aren't for you, if you enjoy a wonderful story full of magic, rather adult themes (including child abuse), great writing, worldbuilding, and astounding characterization, pick up The Longest Journey and use a walkthrough if you need it. A-

Note: Initially I didn't like the movement speed of the character - then I figured out you could double-click to run around. I also thought it was difficult to find where exits to different areas were on-screen - then I figured out if you press "X" it will show you. Keep that in mind while playing if you have the same difficulties I did. Also, as mentioned, the puzzles can be tough and not so obvious. The story, characterization, and world building are what makes this game great - don't let aggravating gameplay choices stop you from enjoying April's adventure, use a walkthrough.

4205556.review:
The Longest Journey is a very epic game, you could even say it was one of the longest journeys I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. Hahaha. No. Okay, enough of that.

The best way to classify this game would probably have to be something like fantasy science fiction. A sort of Lord of the Rings meets Blade Runner. Lord of the Blade Runners. Yeah, sure.

The main protagonist, April Ryan, is caught between two worlds; a world of logic and science (Stark, Earth), and a world of magic (Arcadia). There is also another dimension containing all that is in between. It's an interesting premise but an all too familiar one, yet The Longest Journey executes it fairly well.

The introduction and conclusion to the story are very satisfying, but the main journey is quite empty and void of any depth. The characters are very one-dimensional and are lacking in personality and do not elicit any significant emotional connection. It's basically "travel from point A to point B whilst saving an entire race of people. Now travel from point B to point C and do the same, over and over again."

There are very few strong supporting characters who you will meet along the way, the rest are very forgettable and are bid farewell as soon as they are met. There are some interesting characters, especially one in particular who seems to hold the power of omniscience, but their back story is not explored as much as I would have liked.

April Ryan's attitude, her denial of everything that is happening, is very grating. She comes off as a pretentious teeny bopper but I'm not exactly sure of her age. She has to be in her mid-20s at the very least, yet she acts like such an unenthusiastic, apathetic, ungrateful little shit. If I had the power to travel between dimensions my mind would be fucking blown and I would absolutely love it, but with April it's as if it is a burden. I can understand it from her point of view, but she never reconsiders just how important her task is, but rather complains about it right to the very end.

Honestly, it's a long game. I actually had to force myself to finish because of how bored I was becoming near the end. It's a very slow and sluggish game. Everything, from character animations to voice acting, seems to purposefully artificially extend the game's length just by dragging them out as much as any single person can tolerate. Many, many, many voices are spoken at such a slow pace that it's far easier to rely on subtitles and read through the text, skipping their dialogue completely.

The pre-rendered backdrops are very beautiful and there is some fancy cinematography going on in a few areas, but the character models are ugly and honestly aren't much of a step up from Final Fantasy VII's blocky models. I preferred the sci-fi setting to the fantasy world, it just seemed so much more welcoming and familiar. Although the fantasy setting was sprawling with life, it became a pain to make friends and explain your predicament to every single person you came across. I kinda preferred exploring April's home town and speaking with her friends.

The Longest Journey could have been so much more brilliant had 3D point-and-clicks not taken over from their superior 2D counterparts. It's a shame it became such a huge fad in the late '90s and early '00s, point-and-clicks just don't work in a 3D environment as well as their 2D brethren.

1294258.review: One of the best point and click adventure games of it's time, and in most ways it still is one of the best these days. For a title almost 15 years old, some elements of course  have become dated - the pre-rendered cutscenes are a clean giveaway - but Ragnar Tornquist's ability for story telling more than makes up for this. He created a universe of two worlds where The Longest Journey tells a great story and lays the groundwork for further developments. Dreamfall neatly expands on this and as of Q4 2012 it is clear that he will work on continuing the story in Dreamfall Chapters. If you are a fan of adventure games and you can appreciate a good story development I would recommend The Longest Journey. It's a great game in and of itself and if you have become involved into the world and characyers, you can continue your experience in the sequels.

5382470.review: This was an enjoyable adventure game with an interesting story. The puzzles generally aren't too hard, and while I used a walkthrough to help me when I got stuck (I don't like being stuck for very long), I'm sure it's solveable without hints if you just keep trying things you haven't yet and maybe revisit people and/or places. Also, it seemed like you can't put the game into an unwinnable state, which is great. OTOH, it can be a bit heavy on the story at times and you can't always skip these sections, there's no fast-transport option to zap from one place to another, and it can be a bit linear so if you figure things out before doing certain things you might have to go back and try to trip some flags in order to keep going.  But overall, I thought this was a good game and is worth a try if you like adventure games.

It's long, it's good, it's boundlessly imaginative, and it's a pity that its sequel Dreamfall didn't live up to it.

This game is a story of a girl who lives in the future but finds out she is destined to help save another world filled with magic and fantasy as well as her own world. The beginning of the game drags on a bit but it introduces all of the characters and gets you to care about them and familiarize yourself with the worlds. The game is over 20 hours long so you get your money’s worth and the art style has aged well over a decade. this game has as much attention to character development and twist as a well written novel. 2609648.review:
This game blew me away.

I'm way late to the party on this title, having only discovered and played through it within the past year or so, but I was shocked at how good it was.

A fantastic world, interesting characters, and a great story are all wrapped together in a single package.

The voice acting is all very well done and adds vibrant life to the various characters you meet throughout your journey.

I would even say this is an adventure title for people who don't think they like adventure titles. I went into this game expecting it to not really be my thing or all that enjoyable, and I really couldn't have been more wrong.

Granted, it's not completely perfect. It's dated, for one thing. You can run it in a windowed mode, but unfortunately there's no option to increase the resolution.

There were some parts in the game that lacked a sense of direction, I found myself getting frustratingly stuck at least a handful of times.

Still, it was all worth it for such a fantastic title.

This is by far one of the greatest games I've every played, and when you couple it together with dreamfall, it creates a story so immersive that even after the hours upon hours it took to figure out that you do actually need that rubber duck you fished out of your aparment window after all, you still fall head over heels for the game. 
As far as gameplay goes, this is your typical point-and-click experience - youve got an inventory filled of stuff (some f it you never even use) and you can use those to solve puzzles. But if gameplay is all you really look for in a game, this isn't for you. The Longest Journey is strictly about story and navigating through the world as the charming and resourceful April Ryan.
All in all, I highly recomend this game. It has a story you can't help but become immersed in, fantastic characters, and an origional concept with a very interesting backstory.

Je pense avoir joué à une très grande majorité des p&c, car c'est un genre que j'apprécie particulièrement (pour sa capacité à détenir des dialogues écrits autrement qu'avec une truelle), The longest journey est de loin le meilleur dans la catégorie des "sérieux".

Le scénario, même s'il part d'un principe littéraire qui a fait son âge, est une merveille de finesse. Le personnage d'April Ryan est - de loin -, le meilleur personnage de jeux-vidéo jamais créé à mes yeux, car il est composé avec un souci et une affection totale.
Les lignes sont droles, émouvantes, tristes : c'est simple, l'auteur fait mieux que dans une grosse majorité des romans de fantasy/sci-fi dans la qualité des dialogues. 

Seul bémol, les énigmes sont parfois tordues, et malheureusement (et fort étrangement), les plus folles sont au début du jeu, rendant son accès sans soluce un peu difficile. 

En dehors de ça, c'est un jeu proprement fantastique ; une véritable aventure où l'on chemine en tenant le destin d'une héroïne sensible, drôle, humaine entre ses mains. 

Chef d'oeuvre.

766182.review:
For me this is one of those games that it's almost impossible to take an objective perspective on just because it made such a profound impact on me at a young age. Could it be one of the best adventure games ever made? Most definitely. Maybe even in the top 5. If I had to put on my objective hat and evaluate it I would be forced to admit that it does have some wonky puzzles at times (particularly in the first chapter) and a few instances of somewhat awkward massive exposition dump (particularly the first time you get to Arcadia), but the world it creates, its characters, and more importantly, the way it introduces you to and draws you into that world puts this game in a class all its own--not only among adventure games, but video games in general. 

Anyhow, regardless of its position in the history of gaming as a whole, I do think it's safe to say that there's probably no better adventure game on steam than this. So if you've yet to play it do so now.

950862.review: 92/100 - Though it was a  long journey, I really enjoyed playing this game. The characters, story, and setting are memorable, enjoyable, unique, and life like. Though it is an old style point and click adventure game and the graphics are dated, the puzzles never felt to be too hard or impossible to solve. If the longest journey was a book, it would be the kind where you're reading but after a little bit the words melt away. You're still reading, only you see the entire story in your mind like you're watching a movie, and you will quickly loose track of time as when you next look at the clock hours will have passed. That's not to say that the game is without its flaws - a few npc characters have foul mouths and other elements. However, story and character wise it doesn't get much better or real than this game. It may not be for everyone but I enjoyed it to say the least.

1576889.review: My recommendation for The Longest Journey comes from the perspective of someone who has never played through a point and click adventure game. This game is considered to be a classic in the adventure genre, and I'm sure many would consider it to be an all time great . The aspects of this game that I loved were the art, story, dialogue, voice acting, humor, and music. Be aware that, as I'm guessing is the case with most point and click adventure games, this game is dialogue heavy and focuses on the story. The Longest Journey first came out in 1999 so some graphical aspects of the game are dated, like the 3D characters (which move around on a 2D background). You cannot die in this game and you cannot become permanently stuck, but it can definitely be challenging. I had no hesitation in looking at a walkthrough to help me out when I was stuck. Most of the puzzle challenges are workable if you are persistent. The final item I would reiterated is that the story is very deep and well written

705559.review:
Excellent Point and click adventure! Ties things up and yet the sequal still adds to the storyline.

You play the role of an art student. One day things start happening and you end up in another world. You find out that there are two worlds Stark (our earth) and Arcadia (a magical non technological world). Every few thousand years a person is chosen to make sure the balance between the worlds stays the same. The current person ends up missing. This is where you come in. As you travel between both worlds looking for the current guardian you find out about yourself and your destiny.

This is a LONG game. The tittle is not kidding. The game has numerious locations with lots of side characters. When this game was released it won multiple awards for being one of the best point and click games created.

If you are a storyline style person, this is definitely the game for you. The graphics definitely show its age but the story is very captivating. In fact the story was so good that they made a sequel back in 2006 and a sequel to that one in 2014.

1547235.review: Having never played this game's sequel, I thought it would be novel (and necessary, due to having forgotten most of the details of the complex story) to replay TLJ before taking on Dreamfall for the first time. So the big question is: how does this game (which I considered to be an adventure masterpiece a decade ago) hold up today? The verdict is mixed. On one hand, it nearly perfects the classic adventure formula (click stuff, talk to people, solve puzzles), the number of absurd puzzle solutions are minimal, and the story is well thought out. But on the other hand, the writing, while well-intended, sometimes comes off as amateurish. The script is also extremely verbose and really could have used some serious editing. The graphics, of course, are extremely dated, but that is easily forgiven. All in all, the spirit of the game holds up well, if not the technical side. Assuming you are a fan of the genre and can overlook its dated flaws, it is still fun to play today. A true classic!

Even if you are not a fan of point and click adventures, I highly recommend you play this game, or at least give the demo a go.

How to play this game in windowed mode:
1) open "C:\Documents and Settings\*YOURUSERNAME*\Application Data\The Longest Journey\"
For german users: "C:\Dokumente und Einstellungen\*YOURUSERNAME*\Anwendungsdaten\The Longest Journey
2) open "Preferences.ini" with an text editor (not MSword)
3) delete all and copy this text in there:
[Preferences]
bool_AprilHighRes=1
SfxVolume=1.0
VoiceVolume=1.0
MusicVolume=1.0
bool_Subtitles=1
bool_ShadowsOn=1
bool_DisableWarnings=1
bool_HighResVideo=1
bool_AllowFastForward=0
bool_UseGFX=1
bool_IsFirstTime=1
SaveDir=01
GfxDriver=display

[DirectX]
GfxDriver=display
int_BitDepth=32
bool_IsDoubleBuffer=1
bool_UseHardware=1
bool_StartFullscreen=0
bool_ForceSingleBuffer=0

[SoundSection]
DecompressedBlockSize=16384
WorstcaseFrameRate=10
StreamBlockSize =4096
BlockSupplyLength=32

4) save the file and launch the game
5) If necessary switch between Hardware and Softwaremode in "Preferences.ini"
Softwaremode:
bool_IsDoubleBuffer=0
bool_UseHardware=0

1950581.review: Technisch veraltet und mit unzureichender Bedienung (es gibt weder Hotspotanzeigen noch Hilfestellungen) eigentlich kein Meisterwerk. Rätsel sind auch relativ rar gesäht, dafür aber, wenn man sich auf Pixelabsuchen mit "intelligentem (kontextsensitiven) Mauszeiger" einlässt, durchweg logisch. Der Hauptfokus liegt allerdings auf der Spielwelt. Massenhaft, gut bis sehr gut vertonte, Dialoge, haufenweise versch. toll designte Schauplätze  und viele Charakere und Völker. Jeder Charakter hat dabei seine eigenen Maken und oft auch nen anderen Dialekt. Als Adventure zu Rätselarm und Dialoglastig (um fair zu bleiben: sie arten definitiv zu oft aus) aber als Universum tief und genial. Die Geschehnisse werden in einem nett geschriebenen Tagebuch festgehalten und April (Protagonistin) ist sehr sympatisch. Ein Remake wäre Gold wert.

4354959.review:
The Longest Journey is a point-and-click adventure game that takes place in the parallel universes of Arcadia, a world of magic, and Stark, a world science and technology. 

The protagonist, April Ryan, is an 18-year-old art student living in Stark. She learns that the line between the two worlds is growing thin, causing chaos on both sides. April also learns that she is a Shifter, one who is capable of walking between these worlds, and is then tasked with restoring the Balance between the dimensions before it is too late.

While this game does suffer from some ridiculously hard and obscure puzzels and the 3D character models offend my eyes in 2013, these quibbles must be overlooked if you are to enjoy this wonderful game. 

If you are looking for a game that has a complex and envolving storyline, interesting characters, and high production values - look no further!


I give this game a 10/10

377787.review: It's been called one of the best adventure games of all time, and with good reason.  Compelling story, good visuals for its time, and puzzles that are challenging but not nearly as obtuse as other adventure games'.  The story is a fairly traditional fantasy one with some cyberpunkish sci fi thrown in, but it lays out a really fun world to visit for a while.  (Its sequel, Dreamfall, improves on the ongoing story by moving into less traditional territory, in my opinion.)  If you can get past its very outdated visuals, you'll probably find yourself sucked into it on the merits of its story within an hour.

598863.review: Anyone who cares about writing in games is missing out if they haven't played this game. It's the second-best writing in a video game ever. The only game that beats it is the sequel, Dreamfall. And when I say good writing, I do not mean "good for a video game," I mean outright good.

1563667.review: I really, really enjoy this game. There is no way to die, so you have plenty of time to figure out puzzels, even though you will feel pressured to hurry. This plays more like a point-and-click adventure crossed with a visual novel. The graphics are a bit outdated, but that's ok. The story more than makes up for it.
